item.title: DDD Melbourne 2025: The Lost Art of good README documentation
item.description:
My talk covered a few things around why the developer experience is askew, especially around open source projects, what it means to create good technical content, and deconstructing the anatomy of a good README.

While it was a short session and there was no opportunity for Q&A, people provided good feedback at the end of the talk and even appreciated the fact that there was a talk around docs at the conference. READMEs are deceptively simple files, yet an incredibly powerful mechanism for delivering value.

item.title: TechCommNZ 2024 (Workshop): Building an online portfolio in 90 minutes
item.description:
The idea was to expose folks to a docs-as-code methodology, along with getting their own online version of a portfolio created, something they could keep working on, and experimenting.

My workshop covered the basics of why it is important to have an online portfolio, maintainability and accessibility, and the tools needed to build a portfolio with minimal to no costs (other than the effort of creating and updating it).

item.title: TechCommNZ 2024: Thank God, You're Here
item.description:
In this talk, I talked about:

  • Agreeing that we have an advocacy problem.
  • The art of advocacy and why we need to advocate?
  • Identifying some skills that we can pick up to demonstrate value.

  • Really got me thinking about how I can work to raise the profile of technical writing, rather than waiting for someone else to do it.
  • This is a topic we could all do better at so it was good here Swapnil’s approach.

item.title: Redocly for technical writers
item.description:
As part of my Technical Writer Advocate role at Redocly, I was often asked by other technical writers in the community about they could use Redocly for their API documentation.

I wrote about my experiences with Redocly, and how other technical writers could get started with Redocly products to create awesome API documentation. This article captures the workflow for technical writers wanting to get the best out of Redocly products.

item.title: APIDays Australia 2021: The secret sauce behind successful APIs
item.description:

  • Problem areas with API projects from experience,
  • An API’s journey from a producer as well as the consumer perspectives, and
  • How to use documentation along each step of the API lifecycle.

item.title: TechCommNZ 2019: Making content sustainable
item.description:
In this talk, I question how to make our content sustainable, especially now when our content is growing at an unprecedented rate. Just when we thought we had a handle on user needs, that seems to be changing every minute. What does it really mean to create sustainable content and how do we achieve this?

  • Docs and processes are a mess, but they don’t have to be.
  • Reuse. Reduce. Recycle.
  • Think content first.

item.title: Madworld 2018: What's the deal with Release notes?
item.description:
Product managers swear by them, development managers are keen on producing them and quite so often your developers or engineers will help (grudgingly) craft them.

Release notes are everywhere, be it a product or a process. They are quite often your first point of communication with customers eager to know what’s new or fixed in your product or process. In some instances, they also become the most frequently or commonly accessed content on your documentation site.

item.title: Write the Docs Prague 2016: When bad screenshots happen to good writers
item.description:
“You have your content moving at a swift pace, your documents are getting reviewed in a timely fashion (surprise!) and you are nicely heading towards your release milestone.

The only thing missing are some key screenshots that you need to put in before you publish your documentation. What you get instead are some hideous images posing as screenshots, that were captured randomly, bears no resemblance to your instructions and would make no sense whatsoever to the end user.”

item.title: Justifying the use of Single Sourcing
item.description:
I was invited by Madcap Software to write a guest post for their blog. I wrote about a case study where I had to justify the use of single sourcing at the organisation I was working at the time.

To summarise how the single sourcing strategy worked at the organisation was:

  • Avoided issues with duplication of content. All my content resided in one location, reducing inconsistencies.
  • Set a consistent look and feel across all the documentation projects.
  • Was published for different audiences with different information requirements.
  • Allowed me to adapt quickly to changing requirements or ad-hoc requests.
  • Had complete control over content as well as output format and design.
